text: Why can't Python's raw string literals end with a single backslash?
Technically, any odd number of backslashes, as described in the docs.

code:
>>> r'\'
  File "<stdin>", line 1
    r'\'
       ^
SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal
>>> r'\\'
'\\\\'
>>> r'\\\'
  File "<stdin>", line 1
    r'\\\'
         ^
SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal

text: It seems like the parser could just treat backslashes in raw strings as regular characters (isn't that what raw strings are all about?
), but I'm probably missing something obvious.
